In Locsmánd, for example, the cemetery occupied nearly the entire castle and people were buried in the area of the earthen fort of Szabolcs until 1973. The medieval churchyard (13th century) of the Holy Cross church of Dévény was also used until the end of the 18th century. The same can be demonstrated in numerous Hungarian settle ments. From our excavations, we only mention the medieval Ság (Ságizsidód) village at Ipolytölgyes-Szentmárton, where people buried their dead in and around the church of the village from the late 12th century to the late 18th century (130 graves were unearthed; the coins came from the 12th century to the 18th century, while all the devotional medals came from the 18th century). The two 10th -llth century cemeteries of the ear lier generations were found 900 m southwest of the church. At the same time, two burials with horses from the 10th century (graves no. 34 and 35) were also uncovered on the western side of the small church of Örménykút (1: 18 m, w: 10 m) built in the 12th century: they were uncovered in the churchyard counting 178 graves and among the graves inside the church. There were no similar graves in Somogyvár. The Abaújvár earthen fort is a very good analogue to Somogy vár. A church stood in the centre of its interior area occupying 3.9 ha, just like in Somogyvár (Figs. 1239, 1582, 1583-84, 1998), surrounded by a large churchyard from which 655 and 786 graves were uncovered. The length of the nave was 11.25 m, its width was 7.23 m, the thickness of the walls of the nave measured 1.05 m, that of the chancel 1.25 m. The church was built with apron walling. There were no graves inside the church but there were coins from the 12th-13th centuries both inside the nave and in the graves (see graves nos. 408 and 544). From the 34 burials that contained grave goods, 21 graves contained lockrings and many of the graves contained beads and earrings (Fig. 2253). Both the construction of the church and the opening of the churchyard can be dated from the early 12th century just like the large cemetery uncovered on Kupavárhegy at Somogyvár, the establishment of which can be dated to the first decades of the 1100’s although according to the coins (Figs. 906, 1253, 1489) people had certainly lived and died here from the time of King Andrew I. This is why it is so strange that no earlier burials dated by coins were found although the churchyards were al ready commonly used as burial grounds in the Hungarian King dom from the 11th century. It can evidently mean that the earli est graves have not yet been found around the small, 11th century church of Somogyvár since only 390 burials have been uncovered, or else the cemetery was opened only in the 12th century, or placing coins into the graves (funeral obulus) was not in fashion in Somogyvár. The stray coins found in the cemetery (Figs. 1603-1607) also came from 15th-16th centuries and the oldest of the in situ coins uncovered in the graves was a perforated copper coin of Béla III (1173-1196) in grave no. 299 (Figs. 1809, 1813). Grave no. 383 contained a coin from the 13th century (Figs. 1857, 1859), a coin from the 14th century came from graves no. 176 (Figs. 1647,1650) and 237 (Figs. 1727-1729), and ones from the 15th century were uncovered in graves no. 195 (Figs. 1671, 1673), 209 (Figs. 1681, 1687), 417 (Figs. 1880, 1881), 424 (Fig. 1889), 491 (Fig. 1916) and 522 (Figs. 1931, 1933).



594 SOMOGYVÁR - Szent Egyed-monostor
Regrettably, we do not know anything about the anthropo logical features of the people buried here. This is a common situation in the Hungarian 9th-16th century cemeteries. De spite the fact that thousands of graves have been unearthed at numerous sites, there are barely any completely uncovered me dieval cemeteries and we know next to nothing about the major historical figures: our ancestors. We have archaeological data from 17 Conquest Period and 31 Árpádian Era cemeteries in Somogy county but the bone faces, statures, diseases, blood groups, genetics, kinships of the individuals generally remain unknown. Thus we can only sketch the costumes and the burial rites since the analyses of other aspects (e.g. orientation, depth of the graves, the position of the arms) are irrelevant in a churchyard. Regarding the costumes, the dead buried around the chapel in Somogyvár do not show any peculiarities according to the preserved finds. Beside simple belt buckles, mount-ornamented belts and finger-rings, headdresses decorated with beads and wires are the most attracting articles of wear (grave no. 161: Figs. 1634, 1635; grave no. 162: Figs. 1641-1643; grave no. 208: Fig. 1686; grave no. 229: Figs. 1715, 1717, 1718; grave no. 282: Figs. 1791,1792; grave no. 340: Figs. 1838-1840), a few of which could be reconstructed. An iron dagger (grave no. 313: Figs. 1819, 1820), iron knives (grave no. 217: Figs. 1699, 1696; grave no. 287: Figs. 1798,1799) and a decorated bone strap-end (grave no. 172: Fig. 1639), are unique finds. The last one has exact ana logues in Somogy county and all over the country. These finds are easy to date: the plaque of the mount-orna mented belt (clasp: fig. 904), the bronze belt plaques (Figs. 358, 903), the clasp of the mount-ornamented belt in grave no. 161 (Fig. 1631) and the plaque of the mount-ornamented belt in grave no. 162 (Figs. 1640, 1644) can be dated from the 14th15th centuries, the iron buckle in grave no. 36 (Fig. 1952) came from the Middle Ages, the bone strap-end of grave no. 172 (Fig. 1639) from the 14th century, the iron buckle of grave no. 494 (Fig. 1919) from the Middle Ages, the strap-end with a mono gram (Fig. 1510) from the 16th century, the plain plate strapend (Fig. 929) from the 13th-14th centuries, the silver buckle in grave 234 (Fig. 1723) from the 13th century, the clasp of a mount-ornamented belt (Fig. 1748) from the 15th century, the round bronze buckles in graves nos. 278, 391 and 402 (Figs. 1786, 1788, 1863, 1871, 1874) from the 15th century, the silver lockrings in grave no. 529 (Fig. 1982) from the 12th century, the rings (grave no. 6: Figs. 360, 351,1235, 1236; grave no. 339: Fig. 1833-35; grave no. 352: Fig. 1847; grave no. 377: Figs. 1852, 1856; grave no. 413: Fig. 1878; grave no. 418: Fig. 1879; grave no. 445: Fig. 1902) from the 12th-16th centuries, the beaded head dresses with spiral rosettes (grave no. 95: Fig. 739; grave no.161: Figs. 1633-1635; grave no. 162: Figs. 1641-1643; grave no. 229: Fig. 1717, grave no. 282: Figs. 1791, 1792; grave no. 340: Figs. 1838-1840) mostly from the 14th-16th centuries, but all we could historically learn from them is that people lived and died here between 1000 and 1556. The number of the finds does not afford us to reconstruct either the costume or the contempo rary funeral pomp or customs. We have not found any trace of tombstones or wooden grave posts but the remains of wooden coffins with many iron coffin fittings (Figs. 1767, 1837) and nails were preserved at several places (grave no. 212: Fig. 1689). Even a few locks could belong to coffin boxes. A unique phenomenon was observed in grave no. 306 (Figs 1815-1818): people fended themselves from the haunting spirit even in the 15th century. Uncommonly many bodies were bur
ied lying on the belly (grave no. 287: Fig. 1798; grave no. 370: Fig. 1853) or in a sitting posture (grave no. 153: Figs. 1624,1625; grave no. 174: Fig. 1649) or a crouched position (grave no. 276: Fig. 1784; grave no. 278: Fig. 1787; grave no. 286: Fig. 1797; grave no. 297: Fig. 1807; grave no. 300: Fig. 1810; grave no. 342: Fig. 1841). These phenomena cannot be interpreted without the analy ses of the skeletons. They could reveal if these people were crip pled or culprits according to the medieval concepts (suicides, possessed by demons, Jews, usurers, people who died without the last sacrament, disowned people or incestuous persons) or the deformities were caused by malnourishment. According to medieval beliefs, an improper burial elicited God’s anger. Death is inescapable: the Dance of Death (Toten tanz: Fig. 2263) spares no one. There were only four burials inside the small church of So mogyvár (Fig. 1585), which may imply that it originally worked as an ecclesia baptismalis. In the early times, the people of So mogyvár (urbs Somogy) probably did not bury their dead here but in the cemetery of the Váralja suburbium (established at a yet unknown location). Burying inside funeral chapels became fashionable only after the 16th century in the small rural churches since it was held that there should not be graves in the chancel and the nave where the holy mass was celebrated (Fig. 2254). It became com mon in the 15th century that kings (e.g. King Matthias in Székesfehérvár) and the aristocrats wished to rest in the chancel. The small church was built without a tower (Fig. 1584), and probably a sacristy was later added to its northern side (Fig. 1583) perhaps in the 13th century but the building material was stone just like in the case of the chapel. The buttresses of the eastern side were built together with the semicircular chancel. On the western side, however, the buttresses of the facade are not bound into the main walls. Regrettably, we could not base the theoretical reconstruc tion (Fig. 1584) of the small church on carved stones. Many Hungarian and foreign churches can be cited as close ana logues, first of all the Ellésmonostor chapel, the topographical position of which is very similar as it was built 50 m northwest of the late 11th century monastery. It is 11 m long and 6.6 m broad and it is dated from the early 12th century. Further good analogues are the Esztergom-Zsidód, the Hajdúdorog, the Szentes-Kaján, the Mezőcsát, the Bolt, the Nagygút, the Veliki Gradac and the Glasbach churches, the church of Bribir in Croatia, the Saint Peter and Saint Paul church in Odrepsy (Oskobrh /Nymburk/), the reconstructed parish church of Berg in Austria, and the Szentgyörgy (Kismacs) church near Debrecen, which had an inner length of 16.6 m and an interior width of 4.55 m. As opposed to the former ones, this church did not have a sacristy. The 13.8 m long and 7.1/7.6 m broad church uncovered within the ramparts of the Regöly earthen fort and the churches in the region of Cegléd can also be grouped here. These churches are generally not dated from before the 12th-13th centuries and so their churchyards are also dated from between the 12th-13th-16th centuries. The church of the Saint Giles monastery had already been finished when it was consecrated (September 1, 1091) yet the foundation south of the basilica (Figs. 1960, 1961, 1979, 1980) suggests that some kind of a building must already have stood here before the construction of the basilica, and so the small church was probably not an isolated building from the middle of the 11th century or the early 12th century.



Historical recapitulation 595
People were buried in the western area in front of the main entrance and on the southern side from the last decade of the 11th century the latest until the middle of the 16th century. We have very few data concerning the dating of the graves. Beside the burials with brick frames (grave no. 10: Fig. 1936; grave no. 31: Figs. 1947, 1948), the graves with stone slabs (grave no. 55: Fig. 1955-1957; grave no. 267: Fig. 1969) are also early ones (11th12th centuries), which is supported by the S-terminalled lockrings in graves nos. 31 and 529 (Figs. 1948,1982). It is not known who were buried here: the population of Váralja (suburbium) who served for the castle and probably took part in the construction as well or servicing people who had been settled here.
Church of the monastery (templum, basilica)
The medieval Latin word monasterium came from the name of the Saint John Benedictine monastery of Miistair (Kt. Graubünden) established in the Carolingian period in the last quarter of the 8th century AD, which was pronounced as munistiri in the old high German. But not only convents were called monasterium but also churches that had towers (turris, pinnaculum) similarly to monasteries (ad modum monasterii). Werbőczy stressed that those monasteries were more valuable in which the burial sites of the advowsons and other aristocrats could be found. A stone castle (castrum lapideum) was worth 100 gira, a monastery (monasterium sive claustrum) in which advowsons (patronus) and other nobilities were buried (sepul turam patronorum et aliorum specialium nobilium habens) was also worth 100 gira, while a church with two towers built in the shape of a monastery (ecclesia cum duobus pinnaculis ad modum monasterii fundata) was only worth 50 gira. We cannot really authentically reconstruct the construction history of the royal abbey of Somogyvár in every detail and even the determination of the construction periods is difficult de spite the fact that we have the basic data. The analysis of the carved stone started very late due to various (exterior) causes and so only a few reconstructions could be made (p. 116). Nevertheless, we could exactly follow the building of the foundations of the church of the monastery. Being a church of a royal foundation, probably the bishop of Veszprém (ordinarius) himself determined its place, which seems even more probable since the founding king did not exempt (exemptio) the monas tery from the authority of the bishop of Veszprém (salvo episco pali iure). We do not know when it took place but the construc tion could already start around 1077 at least this can be deduced from Albericus’ document from 1078. According to a late docu ment dux Ladislaus in parochia castri Bihar, inter flumen Kewres, in venatione sua invenit locum, ubi angelico admonitu proposuit construere monasterium in honorem Virginis Ma riae, quem locum Warad nominavit, which means that during hunting, Prince Ladislaus (dux) found a place along the Körös river in the county of the castle of Bihar and, at the admonition of an angel, he decided to found a monastery in honour of Vir gin Mary, and he named this place Várad. Accordingly Ladis laus already founded monasteries when he was yet a prince just like his brother prince Géza had done at Garamszentbenedek (around 1060). The church of Somogyvár is an integrate construction de signed in a single act. The determination and the measuring of
the place of the huge church must certainly have been done with the contemporary units of measure with respect to the ecclesiastic rules of orienting to the east. A church is God’s house, the gate to the Heaven, the chancel of which is the place of eucharistia: the reflection of Heaven and so the eyes must be turned away from the devil toward Christ, that is toward the East (the Good). At sunrise, the east-west axis of the future church is laid down, which is not exact at Kupavár either: it di verges from it by 26 degrees to the north. We do not know if it was so because the event took place not on the day of the spring or the autumn equinox (March 21 and September 23) but at the time of the summer (June 22) or the winter (December 21) sol stice. The title of the church was the indivisible Holy Trinity, its patrons were Saint Peter and Saint Paul (25 June) and Saint Giles (1 September). We do not have data about the laying of the foundation stone although it must have taken place. A wooden cross was raised where the chancel would stand and the bishop consecrated the place of the church. The ap pointed master builder (magister operis, sapiens architectus) first lay out the place of the chancel (and chapels) according to the designs probably exactly as prophet Ezekiel wrote in the Old Testament: “a man was there ... with a linen cord and a measur ing reed in his hand ... The length of the measuring reed in the man’s hand was six long cubits.” A cubit or ell ranged between 45 and 70 cm. There used to be an etalon in the Hungarian Kingdom already in King Saint Stephen’s time, which was pre served in the treasury of the basilica of Székesfehérvár, and it was still there in the 14th century. Accordingly, the basic units of measure were a Roman foot and the somewhat larger Vienna foot (their ratio is 13090 : 14011). A Roman foot (pedum romanum, Fuß) was 29.2-30 cm; a Gaulish-German foot = 33.27 cm; a Benedictine foot = 33.29 cm; a Carolingian foot = 33.233.8 - 34 cm. In the Hungarian Kingdom 1 foot = 31.26 cm; 1 digit = 19 mm; 1 inch = 25.2/26 mm; 1 cubit = 62,5 cm; 1 Buda cubits (which King Sigismund accepted as a national unit of measure) = 2 feet, i.e. 58,4 cm, thus as a German emperor he accepted the Roman foot as a unit; 1 palm = 4 digits; 1 span = 195 mm; 1 step = 3 feet, i.e. 93-94 cm; 1 royal fathom (mensura regali) = 10 feet, i.e. 3.126 m; 1 royal double step = 6 feet = 72 fingers = 1.87 m; 1 Vienna ell = 1.89 m. The measurement numbers (Maßzahlen) and the applied numerical systems (Zahlensystem) were determinant in the Middle Ages. The architect was also a magister geometriae. The medieval measurement system could also be determined by the analysis of the design of the St Gallen monastery. “The existence of such systems is just as clear as the fact that it was one of the determinant factors of the way of thinking of master builders. Beauty manifests itself in the proper measurements. These numbers and the history of their significance belong to the his tory of the art of monastery building but the preliminary studies are missing to it.” The conversions could be checked at several still standing buildings. The measurements made at the Syl vester chapel of Goldbach, which belongs to the Reichenau monastery, the Großendorf, the Lorsch and the Steinbach churches have supported that a medieval foot equalled 3430 mm in Western Europe, and the unit of a building grid (quadra tisches Raster) was six feet, i.e. 2 m. According to our calculations, the devotus architectus at Somogyvár, whose person is regrettably not known, probably used an approximately six metres, i.e. two royal ells long meas uring rod (a rod was 4.5 m long in average) to determine the units (unitas) of the main measurements. This 20 feet long unit



596 SOMOGYVÁR - Szent Egyed-monostor
was 60 cm shorter than the western ones. It could be a measur ing instrument that could be opened as compasses, although we know of the use of a real measuring rope from the Vita of Hugo von Semur abbot of Cluny (1120) (sie mit Seilen den Grundriß der Kirche absteckten), and the process is even depicted in a miniature in the Saint Martin des Champs monastery. Now matter how prudent (prudens) a master was, the theoreticus architectus could only be an ecclesiastic person like Saint Paul who called himself sapiens architectus and as a con scientious master builder designed the church and laid down the foundations (fundamentum posui). The architectural schools probably had pattern books (Musterbücher) but none of them have been preserved in Hungary. After the determination of the apse of the chancel, the width of the nave was marked, which was 34.6 feet, i.e. 10.8 m. The interior wall face of the western facade was pointed out at a dis tance of five times the width (173 feet = 53.9 m). The two aisles, the width of which was half of that of the nave (2:1, i.e. 5.4 and 5.2 m) were divided into 8 squares each, the nave was divided into 8 oblong-shaped units probably with the idea in mind that number 8 was the holy number of salvation, the resurrection, while a square was the symbol of the finite earthly life. The body of the church was divided into a nave and two aisles by twice seven pillars from the chancel and the chapels to the western tower. There are, however, only 12 round pillars (number of the apostles) since the first pair of pillars formed the arch, while the last one was engaged by the towers. “Now therefore ye ... are built upon the foundation of the apostles and prophets, Jesus Christ himself being the chief corner stone; in whom all the building fitly framed together growth unto an holy temple in the Lord.” We know nothing about the builders (operarii), the masons (caementarii), the carpenters (carpentarii) and the co-operators (cooperaturii) who worked on the church of the Somogyvár ab bey. Rémig Békefi thought to have found the sign of the builder of the church on a keystone (Figs. 34, 35), which was probably an error since the signs are not on the visible sides. Not even the exact process of choosing the site is known since the small church must already have stood when the place of the basilica was determined on the southern side close to the deep ditches and so Kupavár was certainly not uninhabited in the 11th century. For that matter, the Benedictine Order did not settle in uninhabited regions since although the rules of the Regula were also respected, their main activity was conversion in the early period. As no trace of an earlier settlement was uncovered under the buildings of the monastery built on the northern side of the church we have to suppose that the place of the monastery was taken into consideration or even determined even if perhaps wooden buildings were standing there, which were later demol ished. The foundations of the church must have been dug in a sin gle event: the foundation ditches are six feet deep (one Vienna ell, Fig. 195) at the western towers, and four feet deep in average at the main walls. But while the foundation shows a herring bone pattern (opus spicatum: Fig. 314) at several places on the southern side, elsewhere it was dominantly built from simple carved stones or, on the northern side, amorphous basalt blocks (Figs. 296, 298) to a significantly larger width under the in aver age 4 feet broad walls (Figs. 335, 337). The downwards widen ing, very bulky foundations of the towers were also built from basalt blocks (Figs. 184,194). As the entire monastery was built on a thick prehistoric settlement layer, not only a strong foun
dation was needed under the main walls but also broad, mor tared beam grids, long-strip footings (Figs. 285, 287, 341, 342, 344, 357, 397) were made from stone and bricks under the col umns to evade sinking. Reinforced foundations with or without post rows can often be observed in the medieval Europe. The foundations of the three semicircular apses constructed on the same baseline were identical, unlike the vertical walls (Figs. 372, 401). The vertical walls were made with a so called apron walling: the main walls of the nave were built from carved sandstone and bricks (opus mixtum) on the southern side, while purely bricks were used on the northern side and also in the northern wall of the north-western tower (T-l) (Fig. 183) but exclusively on this side (Figs. 180, 184). It may indicate two different construction periods or a modification of the design or even the lack of stone. Neither brick kilns nor lime kilns and pitch foundries were found anywhere on the excavated territory, which cannot be explained. The carved stones could be transported here on ax les or on water but a local stone carving workshop must also have existed as it is evidenced by the uncovered tools (Figs. 329, 564, 1015, 1067). There are practically no quarries in Somogy. Compact lime stone could be transported here from Piszke, Tardos or Süttő, coarse limestone from Bajót, Bicske or Sóskút, sandstone from Keszthely, Pécs, Borosjenő, Esztergom, Budakeszi, Csobánka, Nagykovácsi or Pilisszántó and most of the white and the red marble had been quarried in Hungary. The majority of the wall sections were made from rubble. The twice seven wall pillars distributed at even distances on the main walls of the church clearly show both on the interior and the exterior sides (lesenes) the intention of creating a uni form interior and also that the aisles were probably covered with barrel and groin vaults at the start of the construction work. These walls would not have carried a heavier load. The pillars of the nave were relatively soon rebuilt into clear prismatic, square-shaped columns although the Greek cross shape was preserved at several places, as it was definitely dem onstrated by Rémig Békefi. A preserved, 160 cm x 140 cm large column body attests to it (Figs. 342, 343), into which an earlier (late 11th century) carved stone was also built in (Fig. 346). The pillars were plastered and whitewashed (Fig. 282, 285, 287, 335, 341). The same is evidenced by the shapes of the columns (pil lars) engaged in the north-south dividing wall (Fig. 335). The simple shape of the huge church of the Somogyvár monastery, just like for example the church of the Saint Peter and Paul monastery of Hirsau, does not exclude that the aisles were two-storied like in the Virgin Mary cathedral of Székesfe hérvár and the Deák church and it was perhaps also similar to the Saint Lasarus cathedral of Autun (1131) the aisles of which were one-storied. It is, nevertheless, totally impossible that a late gothic reticulated vault was added to the nave of the So mogyvár church in the first half of the 16th century and masses of renaissance carvings were built into the buildings of the ruin ous monastery, which had completely impoverished, dilapi dated and neglected by the first decade of the 16th century, or its church. A significant late gothic-renaissance reconstruction could take place in the 15th century but there is no evidence that the nave got a new vault. Based on the keystones, a reticu lated vault could perhaps be built over the raised and enlarged territory (chorus minor) of the main chapel (chorus). Regarding its ground plan, the Somogyvár basilica stands close to the basilica of Seckau built around 1150, the Stein



Historical recapitulation 597
gaden church (1177) and the Saint Anastasius church of Zára (Zadar) (early 13th century), which have preserved the hori zontal ceiling. The nave of the huge church of the Saint Giles monastery of Somogyvár could always have a flat ceiling or an open roof sim ilarly to the St Gandolf church of Sint Truiden (11th century), the Sancta Maria church of Pomposa (11th century), the church of the Benedictine monastery of Eschau, the Saint Morus church of Amsoldingen, the Saint Peter and Paul church of Pa derborn (11th century), the Saint Michael church of Hildesheim (1033) and the above mentioned cathedral of Zára. The nave rose over the aisles and it was lighted through the windows of the clerestory wall (Lichtgaden) as it can be seen at numerous 11th- 12th century churches (Prüfening /1119/, Niedermünster /1152/, Straubing /1170/, Gurk). The effect of the reform spreading from Gorze in Lorraine was stronger here than the spirituality of Cluny (Cluny II), which was more liable to step over traditions, yet it determined the romanesque period of Eu rope especially in the Mediterranean where Saint Gilles be longed, the 11th century condition of which is however not known. By 1091, the huge undivided interior of the church had al ready been roofed: barrel vaults or flat ceilings covered the aisles and a flat ceiling or an open roof the high nave. An open space opened nearly up to the altars (Heavenly road to Christ’s throne) to the people who entered the vestibule between the western pair of towers (narthex, Á-2/A: Fig. 180) through the western gate of orders of arches but there must have been some kind of a low divider since the notitia of 1091 stressed several times the existence of an atrium as a sanctuary, which certainly had to be separated. In the church of the Csolt monastery (llth -12th centuries), the nave was divided by a north-south running wall at the third intercolumnation from the west 12 m from the western closing wall. This was however a 75 cm thick wall of a shallow (only one foot deep) foundation which can be called the choir screen al though the choir as King Christ’s throne (chorus, sanctuarium, presbyterium) was generally shut off from the Christian lay be lievers (Chorschranken Lettner, chorus maior), and the sepa rated area was raised as Gervasius of Canterbury described it in 1185: there was a wall of marble plates (paries) between the footings of the columns, which surrounded the choir and sepa rated the presbyterium, the body of the church from the rest and the wings (alae). The choir screen also played an important role in Somogyvár (Figs. 8 4 -8 6 , 8 8 -9 3 , 97-98). The atrium was actually a classical architectural form, its original meaning was yard (Vorhof), porch, courting palace, which was bordered by column rows from three or four sides (perystilium) and they were unroofed in the centre. Such was the 8th century Old St. Peter basilica in Rome. Pilgrims gath ered in the atrium in front of the church and this was the only place where those who had not been baptized could stay since in early times the baptizing house (baptisterium) was also lo cated here. In other churches (e.g. in Várad), this was the place of the ordeals, the assemblies of the Holy See and the marriage ceremonies. After the 6th-8th centuries AD, Christian phrase ology also called it a paradise (paradisum, Paradies) or a beauti ful garden (hortus conclusus) after the Persian holy place, holy area (Heiliger Bezirk) expression, which generally had a well (kantharus) in the centre. The names galilaea and vestibulum also occurred when a covered porch was built in front of the church. In the liturgical phraseology, the word atrium was used as the place of burials and of asylum (asylum, Azylrecht, refu
gium). Atriums no longer existed in the gothic church building. This is why it is so important that the role of the atrium was stressed in Somogyvár. In Italy, the Salerno cathedral and the San Ambrogio cathe dral of Milan were built with atriums, and the atrium of Corvey is also famous. The atriums of the Schaffhausen, the Seligen stadt and the Saint Cosma and Damian church of Essen were built in the llth -12th centuries. A specific situation could be observed at Somogyvár since the atrium was built together with the nave and the aisles under the same roof. There were no burials in this space (Á-1-2-3.), and there were naturally no wells or cisterns, while the northsouth dividing wall (Figs. 172, 279, 280, 283, 290, 293, 297, 308, 335) was found in a late medieval condition, that is we found the remains of the wall that separated the western third of the basilica in the 15th or the 16th century. We could not find out, however, what the bulky stone wall of an extremely deep foun dation (Figs. 335, 437) originally looked like, when it was built and how high it was. If it reached up to the top of the ground floor it could support the emporium of the western gallery the place of the organ, the choir members (angels’ choir) and the pilgrims. There could be altars and chapels here with liturgical ceremonies. Only four years had passed from the consecration (1 Sep tember 1091) to the death of King Saint Ladislaus I (29 July 1095) when his body was taken here from the region of Nyitra (or Zólyom) and his probably adorned sarcophagus was placed in the centre of the church (in medio basilicae, in medio domus, in medio templi). King Saint Stephen’s funeral ceremony (cor pus sanctum in medio domus sarcophago candidi marmoris imponitur) and the Gorze reform (ordo Gorzensis: preference of an exterior crypt/Außenkrypta/) were followed just as Mathias Hunyadi did much later. Another similarity could be that just as the Our Lady Virgin Mary church was not finished in Fehérvár in 1038, neither stood the Somogyvár basilica in its full splendour and later shape in 1095. Based on this supposi tion it seems possible that the north-south oriented dividing wall resting on a strong and deep foundation was finished in the middle of the 12th century and it separated the atrium from the consecrated nave and aisles with special attention to the inten sifying respect toward King Ladislaus’ grave since by the 14th century he had become the sacred person of the entire country. This work probably ran in parallel with the construction of the monastery, which gained its full shape in the 12th-13th centu ries, and it was changed only in the 15th century. The southern entrance of the church, which was built to gether with the main walls, implies that the main approach road to Kupavárhegy ran across the ditches, probably a bridge and a drawbridge in the castle wall farther to the east than the mo dern road because without this supposition the southern en trance would be senseless. It also proves that the baptised be lievers and the guests entered the church not through the western gate. The southern gate generally opened also into the churchyard and there was a burial place on the southern side as well. The pilgrims and the penitents who intended to return to the faith must have used the western gate, which was probably adorned with the Majestas Domini statue (Fig. 78), (as the pub lic gate) like ‘Wry-Mouth’ Boleslo (1102-1138) in 1113 who in contrast to the description of the Cronica Polonorum went on a barefooted (pedibus nudis) pilgrimage not to Saint Giles’ relic (ad sanctum Egidium) but to Saint Stephen’s grave in Székesfe hérvár, while at Somogyvár he made a barefooted pilgrimage in



598 SOMOGYVÁR - Szent Egyed-monostor
a hair-shirt to King Ladislaus’ grave. This was definitely so until King Ladislaus’ body was moved to Várad, which did not take place until 1131 but only in the 1170’s when his decorated grave was placed also in the centre of the nave of the cathedral. Nev ertheless, significant relics remained in Somogyvár: on the the ory of ubi est aliquid, ubi totum est. The uncovered subterranean grave resembling a reliquary crypt was probably made after the body of the founder king had been moved to Várad (Figs. 338, 434, 435). Its 5 feet broad structure was left intact by the foundation of the north-south oriented dividing wall, which means that King Ladislaus’ sar cophagus must have stood at the same place, most probably lowered into the earth. It is interesting that one of the brick graves in the churchyard of the Dombó basilica has the same shape on the side of the head (western side) as the reliquary grave of the king (Fig. 435). On the western side of the dividing wall, a bevelled footing was built in a low height (171.15 m) above the supposed marble floor (-3 0 cm i.e. 170.85 m), which was missing on the eastern side (Fig. 308). As far as we can tell to date, the north-south oriented bulky dividing wall was made in the 12th century but it closed the western hall of the basilica only in the 15th century when a late gothic ribbed reticulated vault was built over the chancel and perhaps the aisles. Yet there still existed a passage from the atrium to the nave. It was totally closed with a U-shaped con struction only in the first third of the 16th century. This was also the date when the gates were walled up both in the basilica and at the gatehouse. The transformation of the monastery into a church fort started after 1526 and it progressed in a few years since Bálint Török already had to siege it in the April of 1538 to seize it from Balázs Sulyok whom he had then beheaded. The monastery was defended partly by brick walls (Figs. 319, 1119, 1197, 1199), partly by earthen ramparts (Figs. 2147, 2168) and partly by ditches (Fig. 2206) in the south and the west. Neither historical data nor archaeological evidences tell when and why the builders changed from mixed stone and brick walling to clearly brick walling in the wall section between the chancel and the north-western tower (T -l) in the 11th cen tury or later (Figs. 379-380, 388,1 8 3 -1 8 4 ). It is certain that the north-south transversal wall (Fig. 335), the sacristy (Figs. 407-41 4 ) and the eastern buttresses (Figs. 388-389) were built from ashlars and rubble later than the main walls and the towers of the church. The sacristy was made from finely carved ashlars (opus romanum) yet in the 12th cen tury. But as the northern main wall of the church had to be pulled down because of the building of the southern entrance of the sacristy (Figs. 407-40 8 , 416) and the southern ambry (ar marium), it is possible that, with certain modifications in the design, the sacristy was built soon after the construction of the basilica and this is the reason why bricks were used here. How ever, the fact that also mixed walling materials were used in the buildings of the monastery contradicts this supposition. We have not found in situ original floor from the 11th cen tury church so we can only suppose that the nave was paved with the red marble slabs (Tardos or Piszke marble?) found in a secondary position. Later (last third of the 15th century), they were replaced by quadrangular limestone slabs but only east of the north-south dividing wall (Fig. 369). A brick floor was also preserved under the limestone slabs in the nave (Figs. 363, 370), but it extended only until the fourth step of the choir. We did not find a similar brick pavement in side the basilica but the abbot’s chapel was paved with bricks of the same size and firing in the eastern wing of the monastery
(Figs. 884, 907, 908) just like the new cloister of the recon structed monastery (Figs. 601, 607,609). The original floor level was higher than the limestone slab pavement (170.51 m -170.54 m), which can be observed in the foundation of the northern wall of the western atrium (Á-1-2-3.), the long-strip footings under the pillars, the earliest raising of the chancel (Figs. 285, 287, 363, 370) and the level of the edge bevelling on the western side of the north-south dividing wall. The limestone slab pave ment was adjusted to the prismatic pillars and it is also contem porary to the last raising of the chancel (171.33 m, Fig. 363), which was paved with the same limestone slabs and which could be approached on seven steps. The raised chancel had simple buttresses in the north and the south, which did not rise over the level of the raised chancel. From the gates of the basilica (templum, basilica), the south ern one was the best preserved (Fig. 316). Its cylindrical or halfcylindrical columns and the tympanum did not survive only the jamb stones and the wall corners defied the ravages of time. Recent analyses afford the supposition that the rosette-orna mented archivolts (Figs. 14, 22, 40, 64, 7 0 -7 2 , 109, 185, 306, 312, 331, 479, 2295) originally decorated the southern gate (Fig. 2296). The sharp separation of the guilloche and palmette carvings (Figs. 4 0 ,4 3 ,7 0 , 80, 81, 8 3 ,1 1 0 ,1 1 9 ,1 2 0 ,1 2 6 ,1 2 7 ,1 2 9 ,1 9 6 , 306, 346, 543, 547, 581) does not seem justified. We have to definitely count with Croatian-Dalmatian stone carvers in Somogyvár. Judged from the iconography of the 10th-13th century Ita lian, German and Spanish churches, the southern side belonged to the Old Testament with first of all pictures of David’s king dom and also depictions of Jesus’ childhood, his mother Virgin Mary, Christ’s miracles, his walk with the cross and Christ’s fol lowers. So it is possible that the rosette-ornamented gate arches were Mary’s symbols. The semicircle itself is Jesus’ symbol. So it is also not accidental that a depiction of Samson’s com bat with the lion (Fig. 317), who was Jesus’ predecessor in the Old Testament, was found here close to the southern gate simi larly to the reliefs in the Saint George church of Ják and on the southern side of the Giant Gate of the Stephanskirche in Vi enna. It must have been the same in the cathedral of Pécs as well (Fig. 2297). Regrettably we do not have authentic data about all the ornaments of the southern gate. However, there must have been several figurái reliefs walled in under the segmented cornice arches running under the roof on the exterior face of the southern wall (Fig. 107), a number of which has been preserved (Figs. 55, 56). The western gate was found in a very poor condition: practi cally the lower fragments (wall corners) of the northern jambs of the orders of arches of the gate have been preserved (Figs. 167, 168, 173, 175, 177). No trace of a pier was found even on the threshold stone but there must have been cylindrical gate columns: four of them on both sides. As the Heavenly Jerusalem was illustrated on the western side of the churches, Christ, Master of the World, the Last Judgement and most probably also the Pantocrator relief (Fig. 78) were placed in the tympanum of the western gate or over the archivolt of the gate similarly to the gate of the Nevers church. But here the griffon (Fig. 77) maybe together with the so-called Spinario (Fig. 107) could be on the western facade since both the griffon and the lion were the symbols of the Sun and, at the same time, the purification, Christ’s resurrection and ascension. The relief of an angel with a cross could also be placed on the western side (Fig. 103). A few of the numerous carved stones found in front of the western gate probably



Historical recapitulation 599
came from the archivolt of the gate. These were first of all the stones of ovolo frieze or spiral motives (Figs. 12, 19, 23, 30, 113, 114, 171, 176, 288, 291, 893, 909, 1115, 1124, 1126, 1200, 1526, 1544-46, 1548, 1549, 2035, 2145). A few of these stones were later built in at various places. The reconstruction of this gate was prepared (Fig. 2303). Another possibility is a simple gate like that of the church of the 12th century monastery of Petersberg bei Halle since sim plicity was the general tendency in the 12th-13th centuries, which is evidenced by numerous examples on the territory of the Hungarian Kingdom as well. No data help the reconstruction of the 3 feet wide (93 cm) doorway of the sacristy (later side chapel) annexed to the north ern side of the basilica (Figs. 407, 416). A few stones with palmettes (Fig. 80) could belong to this door. We also know next to nothing about the northern door(s) that opened into the clois ter of the monastery: it perhaps resembled the northern gate of the Riga cathedral. The only certain thing is that it opened into the cloister and could be richly decorated according to the pre served fragments. The remains of the gothic gate are monu mental (Figs. 2353, 2354). There is, however, a so-called cheq uered ornament as well (Fig, 2213), which was taken apart at the reconstruction of the monastery (?) and a piece of it was thrown into the ditch of the fortification (p. 116/a). From the buildings of the Saint Giles monastery, only the southern wall of the church remained to a height that at least the places of various elements could be determined. The trace of a niche was found in the western wall in the height of 172.11 m (the height of the preserved wall crown was 173.6 m). It can not be called the ledge or the bench of a window since it was very low although its concave arch was covered with two “stepped” and strong plasters (Fig. 293). The shape in the south ern part of the sacristy can be called a bench (Fig. 408). The jambs and mullions or real window frames can also be found among the stone relics first of all from the monastic buildings, and a few fragments of finely finished rosette win dows (Maßwerk) have also been found (Fig. 2148), which cer tainly came from the church. There were rabbets for glass panes in the long and narrow (3 feet) windows, while they were missing from the tracery windows of the monastery (Figs. 2152-2155). Nevertheless, later (15th century) round window panes (Butzenscheibe: Fig. 1335) of a diameter of 108 mm were found in the debris in the water trench. For a long time, people could not make large and monochromatic glass panes in the Middle Ages, the windows were covered with planks, mucous membranes, oil-paper or thin leather to shield them from cold and wind. Actually each window was associ ated with every wall pillar and column class. A few coloured, painted glass pane fragments were also found (Figs. 424, 928, 1928). So, there could be painted glass windows here, just like in Esztergom (1329), Visegrád and Garamszentbenedek (1375). Remains of glassworks have not been found in Somogyvár: they probably never existed since glass was im ported from Venetia and Germany although many glaziers (laborator vitrorum) worked in the Hungarian Kingdom from the 15th century (Fig. 2323). The inscribed tombstone of only a single person has been preserved from those who were buried on the territory of the basilica (János Zathai: Figs. 73, 74): he died after 1529. Among the remains of earlier funeral monuments (tumba) (Figs. 31, 32) there is a fragment with a date (1524). The stone slab was asso ciated with the Thurzó family (Fig. 75). Its origin is uncertain and it has been lost. There were no burials in the western tow
ers, the northern sacristy (chapel), the atrium and the narthex between the towers. There were five ossuaries in the nave beside the reliquary grave, and each an ossuary in the northern and the southern aisles (A-E). All the ossuaries were disturbed, they contained the remains of many individuals (455), and there were many disturbed stray bone finds (177 individuals: 88 males, 52 fe males and 37 infants). We do not know who they were but males, females and infants were equally present among the per sons buried in the basilica. It is regrettable that due to the sig nificant disturbance we could not uncover graves of abbots (dignitaries) or members of the elite. The southern chapel of the basilica originally probably re sembled the chancel of the 12th century All-Saints chapel of Regensburg with two lower and two upper romanesque win dows and an altar. The foundations and the steps of the mensa have been found (Fig. 368). The chancel extended to the arch in the llth -12th century and the old choir screen must also have stood in this line. The “Conversion of the Barbarians” (Figs. 8 4 -8 6 , 8 8 -9 3 , 480) was one of its marble tablets, and probably the marble reliefs in fig ures 547, 549 and 914 also came from here. The iron mounted chest (Fig. 381) found in the north-eastern quarter of the chan cel contained human bones, which can be called holy relics only in the sense that they probably came from a prominent ecclesi astic person. We know little about the contemporary ornaments of the interior of the church. A marble font was found in a house of the village (Fig. 2309). From among the ecclesiastical objects, a 12th century pro cessional crucifix (Fig. 333), a 14th century footed table cross or the figure on the foot of a candlestick that held the coat-of-arms (Fig. 1530), small bronze incense vessels (Figs. 264,1157,1305), fragments of bronze bells (Figs. 305, 310, 1066, 1506, 1595, 2191, 2196), iron clappers (Figs. 266, 562, 1350, 2167), bronze hand-bells (Figs. 560, 2177, 2197) and the iron clapper of a hand-bell (Fig. 1247) can be mentioned. Numerous altars must have stood in the church, not only in the chapels but also at the pillars. There were ornamental bald achins as well. An impost was also preserved with the start of the rib, mortises and the remains of a coloured fresco. The twoedged sword of a 13th-14th century type could belong to a scene. Its exact place is not known it probably came from the ceiling of one of the side-chapels (2311). The walls and the pillars were plastered and whitewashed: this can be observed on the uncovered plaster fragments with coloured painting. Beside frescos, statues could also stand in the church. Mary’s statue with the infant Jesus (Fig. 118) could stand in front of the wall. A monumental standing figure (maybe of Saint Peter or Saint Giles), the bottom of which was found by the monument protection workers, could stand in one of the aisles. Their age can only be determined by stylistic traits. We associate them with the large-scale construction works in the 12th-13th centuries when the cloister was built. The ribbon decorated shoes, the long gown and the cloak reflect a high standard sculptural work and show many similarities to the statues of the churches of Provence (Saint Gilles, Arles, Figs. 2315, 2316). The torso of an angel (Fig. 2312) was a fragment of a larger relief, which could decorate a gate but we cannot be certain about it since the workers could not recall where they had found it. The so-called dragon stone was found within the similar circum stances (Fig. 2314) perhaps in the cloister of the monastery.



600 SOMOGYVÁR - Szent Egyed-monostor
The builders of the church (carpenters, masons, stone carvers) used simple power machines: slopes, pulleys, levers. The walls themselves held the beams of the scaffolding as they were pulled up higher and higher. The holes of the beams have been preserved (Figs. 379, 382). Certain people pulled up the walls, while others prepared the vaults. Regarding the origin of the master builders, there must have been people from France, Italy and Dalmatia among them. ■ It can be determined from the preserved vault ribs that gothic rib vaults were built in the church, perhaps also in the aisles and the chapels in the 13th-14th centuries, or romanesque groin vaults had been constructed before them since such vaults already existed in Senlis, Soissons, Chartres, Rouen, Tours, Narbonne, Chalon sur-Marne or Faon and even in Zára in the 12th century. Rib vaults with gothic keystones were made later as well (14th-15th centuries) but this work cost very much, and so we cannot presume a serious and de manding construction work in Somogyvár after King Mathias’ reign (1458-1486). The monastery reforms that came to life in the Hungarian Kingdom as well (1337,1490) did not affect the old romanesque churches of the monasteries, among them the Somogyvár ba silica, to a degree that they were completely reconstructed. There were naturally monastery churches that were completely rebuilt like the one in Garamszentbenedek where a gothic church was raised in the place of the romanesque three-aisled basilica, but many churches were left in their original forms. Many western churches and monasteries were preserved in this condition, among others in Stein am Rhein, the Saint George church of Reichenau, the Benedictine monastery church conse crated to the All Saints in Schaffhausen, the Benedictine church and monastery of Wagenhausen and the Alpirsbach monastery. We can add the Hungarian monasteries like the Cistercian church in Pilisszentkereszt (which was nearly exactly the same size as the Somogyvár church) where the romanesque groin vault was left in all the three aisles. The preserved ribs evidently attest to it. The cloisters and the buildings of the monasteries were, however, rebuilt at many places in the second half of the 15th century. The same happened in Somogyvár where the uncov ered consoles (Fig. 11) could belong to a ribbed groin vault more probably in the monastery than in the church. The bold supposition of a few researchers was astonishing: accordingly "immense works started” in Somogyvár in the first third of the 16th century when the entire nave (!), even the west ern third separated by the north-south wall, was covered with a late gothic-renaissance reticulated vault decorated with ro settes. “The restoration of the Somogyvár abbey emerges from the late gothic construction works of South Transdanubia in the 1510's regarding both its dimensions and quality. The mag nitude of the reconstruction of the huge romanesque basilica rivals with the one decade earlier rebuilding of the cathedral of Pécs.” This theory is based on a wall pier head (Fig. 50), two rib junctions (Figs. 34, 35), the fragment of an open cusp (Fig. 49) and two consoles (Fig. 11) completed by “numerous carvings” None of the listed items were recovered during our archaeo logical excavations (1972-1976; 1980-1989). Actually, there is not a single really characteristic renaissance carving in the pre served lapidary material although shapes of a late renaissance semblance can be observed on several items (Fig. 982, 1519). It naturally does not mean that the existence of a reticulated vault is doubtful in itself only that it did not cover the nave and was
not built in the 16th century. If the statement concerning the wide arch of the ribs is true, it can perhaps be the vault of the choir, which was enlarged and raised in the 15th century. The aisles were probably covered with a diamond-shaped vault although it cannot be proved. A groin vault is also possi ble. The monastery of Somogyvár was still fairly rich in the early 15th century (although the income of the abbot did not surpass 90 gold forints which equalled 9 thousand silver denars). The situation changed after 1411 when King Sigismund donated the Somogyvár oppidum with the castle of old walls to the Marczali family and a feud emerged between the monastery and the town of the Marczalis. Around 1417, the Somogy monastery was no longer a branch of the Saint Gilles abbey. Mathias donated the advowson of the royal monastery to János Faki Thuz Slavonian Ban but he soon took it back and passed over to prebend Dénes Fegyverneki who became the renovator of the Somogy abbey. King Mathias described the Saint Giles monastery in his letter to the pope in 1467 as a mon astery "in an extreme dilapidation”, which he intended to return to its old pomp. Fegyverneki and his successor Domokos Kálmáncsehi (from 1483) could be the two abbots who had the church and the monastery rebuilt in a quarter of a century (1467-1493). The saddle-roofed nave and the half-saddle-roofed aisles were covered with pottery tiles. Nothing remained from the decorated floor tiles although a fragment of the decorated stone slab (Fig. 1479) has been preserved. The decision about the reformation of the monasteries was brought at the large chapter held on the Szent Márton hill in 1510. In 1512, eight abbeys united and theoretically a largescale renovation followed this event. The material of the archaeological excavation indicates in stead that the majority of the preserved (merely indicative yet decisive) remains of daily life came from the 13th-15th centu ries although certain find types existed in the 16th century as well. But there was no longer a teeming life after 1500 since only five sick lay brothers inhabited the monastery and the fortifica tion of the monastery started after Mohács. The flourishing time of the Somogy monastery was evi dently the 13th-14th centuries. The 12th century was the time of large constructions. Despite the difficulties in the 13th cen tury, Somogyvár became one of the loca credibilia in 1224 where numerous documents were edited between 1254 and 1543. It had an annual income of 150 silver marks in the 14th century (1332). However, the condition of the monastery dete riorated by the early 15th century. Renovation really started here just like in Pannonhalma in the second half of the 15th century but unlike there, it was never finished. The character and distribution of the finds uncovered dur ing the excavations mirror this situation. It is especially true in the case of ceramics, glass wares (Figs. 174, 451, 460, 465, 624, 886, 9 2 2 ,925,947,1466, 2159), horseshoes (nearly one hundred items), spurs (more than fifty items) and the tableware (mainly the knives /250 items/ since neither forks nor spoons, not even shell spoons were found during the excavations). Many other find types must be considered from the respect of chronology like first of all the large number of book cover mounts (42 pp) although the valuable books of the monastery that had been collected for centuries were obviously destroyed in a single event after the middle of the 16th century, so they date first of all the ransacking of the monastery and the library



Historical recapitulation 601
but they also indicate the growing number of codices from the 13th century to the end of the 15th century. The earliest horseshoes were rarely fullered, the horseshoes of scalloped edges were rather prepared with caulkins or small heels (Figs. 432, 950, 1478, 1755) in the llth -12th centuries. The 13th -14th century types were more numerous (Figs. 454, 459,586,836,892,1097/4,5,1193,1195,1209,1469,1498,1505, 1514, 1553, 1597-98, 2102, 2042) where the support of the horseshoes or their soles (plate shoes) were broad and flat, each three holes were made in the fullers for saddle horses and mules, while 3 holes were on the outside and 4 on the inside of the shoes of draught horses. The holes were either on the fron tal sides of the horseshoes (for the forelegs) or in the frontal two thirds (hind legs). At that time, horseshoes were generally made without heels or with low triangular, wedge-shaped caulkins. A significant number of the 15th century types were found: they were generally made with high, conical heels (Figs. 459, 565, 844, 848, 1062, 1097/1,2,3,6, 1430, 1552), deep fullers and the branches were pointed, often with turned up frontal edges. Only a few items represent the 16th century types (Figs. 269, 1150); the earlier forms probably survived. An early modern pe riod horseshoe was also found (Fig. 2200). As horseshoes gen erally do not endure more than two months of use, the number of the discarded horseshoes indicates the character and size of the stock of horses and the extent of traffic and transportation. Spurs also belong among the easily datable objects, from which large series can be composed. The complete lack of the 11th century spurs with pyramidal, spherical or conical pricks is striking. Types with straight and then arched branches, short knobbed necks and rings appeared in the 12th century (Figs. 536, 585). Items with raised centrals were in fashion in the 13th14th centuries: they are represented with the highest number (Figs. 567/2,4, 1467, 2118). On these items, buckles or orna mental plaques were often attached to the loops at the termi nals of the arched branches (Fig. 2174) and six- or eight-pointed stars-shaped rowels sat on the short neck (Figs. 275, 953,1482, 1511, 1772, 2063). Spurs with branches bent at a right angle (Fig. 1472), then ones with double loops (Fig. 1772) appeared in the 15th century. Armoured knights preferred large rowel spurs with pulled up centres and long necks from the second half of the 15th century (Figs. 536,1338,1527), although the types pre pared with short, up-curved necks also survived. The stray finds that got into the museum of Kaposvár from Somogyvár also came from the 15th-16th centuries. A few of the knives are fragmentary yet astonishingly many knives were found in the large find material (altogether 149144 numbered finds were taken into inventory from the excava tions). Some of them are carving knives (Figs. 456, 1356, 1590, 2083), others are early, 12th-14th century, short-bladed tanged knives with wooden or bone handles (Figs. 528, 851/2, 976, 1359, 1555, 2094, 2117), but most of them belonged to the ta bleware. Several types are known from them. The most com mon ones had long tangs and the covers of the bone (Figs. 1073, 1394,2026,2057) or wooden handles were closed with heart- or shield-shaped copper plaques (Figs. 268, 535, 917, 1042, 1073, 1217, 1394, 1512, 1590, 1799, 2001, 2029, 2037, 2082, 2117, 2131). There are knives on which a riveted copper plaque deco rated the base of the blade. Most of them came from the 15th century. There were a few Steyr knives as well with or without the mark of the factory (Fig. 1590). Naturally, many items can be dated from the 16th century (Figs. 268, 1366), which were dated by numerous 16th century coins in the cellar of tower T-2. Fewer knives had rounded handles (Fig. 986).
The monastery
The church and the monastery had a uniform design although they were not built at the same time. However, certain con stancy characterised both churches and monasteries. A con stancy of five thousand years can also be observed in the case of the famous Cluny. The construction of the cloister around the garden (ornamental yard) was most probably already started in the 12th century but it was finished only in the first third of the 13th century. The columned-arcaded wall of the cloister was segmented by single and twin columns alternating with clustered five-fold columns (Figs. 26, 39, 111, 115, 122, 4 9 9 -5 0 5 , 506, 510-512, 532, 548, 550, 570-580, 659, 801, 946, 1055, 1117, 1137, 1139, 1268, 1404, 1515, 1520, 1529, 1575, 2053, 2055, 2105, 2143, 2144, 2176). The reconstruction was prepared according to this example in the north-eastern corner of the cloister. The reconstruction was not successful either from a theo retic or a practical respect (Figs. 2329-2330). The Árpádian period cloister stood in its original form until the first third of the 15th century. We know nothing about the ornamental garden. The subter ranean part of the cistern was preserved in an intact condition without the channels and the funnel in the south-eastern quar ter of the yard (Figs. 483, 485, 486, 489). A gravel water filtering solution could however only be observed at the pedestal of a statue close to the north-western corner (Figs. 553, 554). There must have been a water basin over the pedestal, which has not been preserved. The cylinder of the pulley that helped hauling water from the cistern is also missing. A bronze pulley (Fig. 835) could be used for conveying goods upstairs (Figs. 2333, 2334). The archaeological investigation of the Saint Giles monas tery of Somogyvár was started at the same time (in 1972) as the excavations of the Dömös church and manor house and the Benedictine abbey of Garamszentbenedek. László Gerevich di rected the former work and Alojz Habostiak and Stefan Holcik the latter one. The only information about the four years of ex cavations is included in a booklet of 22 pages edited on the oc casion of the Illrd International Archaeological Congress of the Slavs organised in Bratislava in 1975. In the followings, we give a summary of it, the first time in the Hungarian research, since it is the most important analogue of the Somogyvár abbey. Based on the close similarities it also seems possible that the master builders who had worked here went over to Somogyvár after 1075 since the Garamszentbenedek basilica was the first church of this type on the territory of the Hungarian Kingdom. Numerous conclusions can be drawn from the comparisons, which have not yet been exploited by Hungarian research. First an irregular ellipsoid, 60 m wide and 380 m long castle was built on a territory of ca 2 hectares on a 400 m x 150 m large, north-south directed hill ridge in an altitude of 200-220 m a. A.S. on the western side of the Garam river at an important road to Nyitra (Fig. 2335). Thirty-forty metres deep natural de pressions defended the hilltop in the east, the south and partly the west, and gullies bordered it in the west. Artificial fortifica tions were built only on the northern and partly the western sides with a gate toward the settlement. (The situation was very similar at Somogyvár only the southern side had to be fortified here, and the settlement also lay in this direction). Ramparts and ditches defended the fortification and a i m broad stone wall (Steinmauer) was built along the edge of the hill. According to the archaeologists, a timber-laced clay wall was built inside the stone wall to a height of 3 m. A wooden palisade and a wall



602 SOMOGYVÁR - Szent Egyed-monostor
walk (Laufgang) were built on top of the rampart. From all these only the burnt, charred wood remains (Verkohlte Reste) have been preserved. There are no evidences in the preliminary re port that these defence works belonged to the so-called late Great Moravian period (10th century). It seems more probable that the settlement traces and the uncovered finds (asymmetri cal ploughshare, spur /Reitersporn/, strike-a-lights, querns, shards) cannot be affiliated to the invented “Slovakian Gate” settlement network instead they belonged to the Petend village (first mentioned in 1209) of the 10th -llth century Hungarian State, the parish church of which was built in the 13th century and consecrated to Saint Giles. It used to stand in the place of the actually standing 17th century church but only its tower has survived. According to the archaeologists, the inhabitants of the first settlement buried their dead in the churchyard of the monastery church (die Toten bei der Klosterkirche begruben), since they did not yet have a church of their own (keine eigene Kirche). The excavations have supported this idea. The excavations went as deep as the rocky base (Niveau der Felsunterlage) in the northern and southern parts of the yard of the monastery where early ceramics were found. (The subsoil was marly loess at Somogyvár-Kupavár, this is why long-strip footings were necessary). The archaeologists deduced from it that the monastery was built on the highest point (um den höchsten Geländepunkt) of the early village sometime around 1060. (At Kupavár of Somogyvár, the basilica did not stand on the highest point.) The first church was built in 15 years and Saint Benedict was its patron saint. It had been finished when it was consecrated in 1075. Fifty cm deeper, Nándor Knauz and Ferenc Storno found the remains of the first church inside the gothic church in 1882. The semicircular shrines separated by apsidal, straight wall sec tions display an uncommon shape (they did not exist in So mogyvár). The church was divided into three aisles by the marked five pairs of prismatic pillars. Its entire length was 32 m, the width 14.5 m. Actually, we have to count with twice six pil lars since there must have been pillars at the interior corners of the western towers. Strangely, no gate is marked between the bulky pair of towers, which slightly jutted out from the plane of the walls (just like in Somogyvár); it is true that no gate is marked on the southern side either. The 11th century church was originally paved with bricks. (In Somogyvár, only the chancel had a brick pavement.) The original monastery was built on the southern side of this church (das Kloster schloss sich an der Südseite an die ro manischen Kirche an), of which especially the southern wing (hauptsächlich in seinem Südtrakt) was unearthed during the excavations. An irregular quadrangular ornamental yard (Paradieshof) stood in the centre enclosed by the buildings (rund um welchen sich die Klostergebäude befanden). An ar caded cloister (Arkadengang) ran on all the four sides. Four construction phases (vier Bauphasen) could be differentiated at the 11th-14th century monastic buildings. Both the church and the monastery of Garamszentbenedek were completely reconstructed (gänzlicher Umbau) in the 14th15th centuries. The entire length of the church was 38.24 m, its width 18.15 m, and the height 15.79 m. The romanesque basi lica was replaced by a three-aisled hall church and a new mo nastic building unit (ein neues Klostergebäude) was raised on its southern side, the dimensions of which were more-or-less identical to those of the earlier one. From this monastery, only a wing of the cloister has been preserved on the northern side
(ein Flügel des Kreuzganges an der Nordseite), the rest of it were uncovered during the excavations in 1972/74. Based on the still standing gothic walls, the layout and the functions of the downstairs rooms could fairly exactly be determined (lassen sich verhältnismässig genau Lage und Funktion der Parter reräume bestimmen). Naturally, analogues had to be used (Szá zává, Pannonhalma, Praga, Pozsony). The southern wing of the monastery was nearly completely uncovered in the entire width (die ganze Breite) and nearly the entire length (ein wesentlicher Teil der Länge) together with the cloister and the (parapet) wall of the arcade of the cloister (Arkadenmauer) on the eastern side. It could be determined that the exterior walls of the eastern building of the existing features were gothic (die Umfassungs mauern des östlichen Gebäudes des heutigen Objektes gotisch sind). The western wing (Westtrakt) probably contained noth ing but the wing of the cloister (nur aus einem Arm des Kreuz ganges). This is an important analogue to Somogyvár since the situation was the same here in the 12th-13th centuries (Fig. 1047). The width of the eastern wing (Osttrakt) of the original monastery without the arcaded corridor (Arkadengang) can be read from the width of the actually standing buildings. The sac risty illustrates the layout of the rooms. This was the northern most room (Raum) of the eastern monastic buildings. To date it only contains the one-time “lower sacristy” (untere Sakristei). The “upper sacristy” (obere Sakristei) was later turned into a chapel (Kapelle). The large chapter house (ein grosser Kapiteisaal) lay south of the sacristy, to which a late gothic chapel of a polygonal closing was annexed in the 15th century, which jut ted out from the bulk of the monastery (aus dem Körper des Klosters hervorragte). Only the main walls (Umfassungs mauer) have been preserved from the chapter house and the annexed chapel. (In Somogyvár, the chapter house was also next to the sacristy from where the abbot’s chapel opened: Figs. 939/A and 884). The original length of the eastern wing could be determined from the balcony (Erker) on the eastern facade (Ostfassade) and from a small break (aus einem leich ten Knick) in the renaissance open arcade opening to the yard. The arcade wall (Arkadenmauer) of the cloister was covered in the closed yard (Hofraum). An arch of a gothic vault (ein go tischer Bogen) was preserved from the eastern cloister (Arkadengang): it connected the sacristy and the actually standing vestibule (Vorhalle). There was a 4.9 m x 9 m large quadrangular room (ein quadratischer Raum) in the southern elongation (in der Verlängerung) of the eastern gothic cloister. It was already in the southern wing of the monastery (südli cher Klostertrakt) and it housed the staircase (Treppen) to the first floor (in das Stockwerk) of the eastern wing. A small staircase can also be supposed in the north-eastern corner of the cloister. A 4.6 m x 12.3 m large room occupied the largest part of the southern wing (südlicher Klostertrakt) with a cellar (Keller) under it. The basement (Souterrain) of this room was originally covered with a barrel vault (Tonnen gewölbe), which was found during the excavations in 1973. The room over the cellar (basement) probably had a ribbed groin or a reticulated vault (Kreuz- oder Netzgewölbe mit Rippen), the fragments of which were found in the filling of the cellar. From the middle of the 15th century, this room was probably heated by a large, decorous tile stove (Kachelofen). Numerous stove tile fragments (Ofenkachelnfragmenten) were found in the filling (in der Verschüttung) of the cellar (Souterrain), which could be reconstructed. (Barely any exclusive stove tiles were



Historical recapitulation 603
found in Somogyvár.) There were ordinary items among the tiles with relief ornaments and other types as well. This room was probably the dining room, the refectory of the monks. This supposition is supported by the kitchen utensils and kitchen wares that were uncovered in the western part of the room. The kitchen (Küche) was probably next to the refectory on the western side, from where a single-armed staircase (Treppenhaus) led into the cellar. (In Somogyvár, the kitchen, with a cellar under it, was also on the western side of the refec tory.) The walls of the kitchen were not uncovered since the foundations of an old round building of a diameter of close to 3 m came to light where the kitchen had been supposed. A brick stove (Ziegelofen) was found near this round building 200 cm under the actual level of the yard. The cells (Zellen) of the monks, that is the dormitory (Dormitorium), and the lodging of the abbot (Abtwohnung) were on the upper floor (im Stockwerk) of the eastern and the southern wings. (The Somogyvár monastery was probably also two-storied but we did not find a staircase: a part of the eastern wing is condition ally interpreted as a staircase.) The workshops (Werkstätten) and the economic buildings (Wirtschaftsgebäude) probably stood farther from the central buildings. (The situation was the same in Somogyvár where probably a butcher’s shop was found beyond the water trench on the eastern side.) The irregular quadrangular yard (Hofraum) measured 16 m x 21 m. It was bordered by the arcades of the cloister on all the four sides. The cloister was probably one-storied (ebener dig), similarly to the one in Somogyvár. A part of the cloister at the church wall and the upper storey that can be found here were built at the turn of the 15th-16th centuries (Überbauung). It also adjoined the older wing of the monastery but it was not vaulted (kein Gewölbe) since there were only each a single but tress (Stützpfeiler) in the middle of the eastern and the south ern wing of the cloister. The same can be supposed in the west ern wing, which has not been uncovered. Each wing of the cloister seems to have originally been vaulted. In the cloister, the groin vault had six panels on a quadrangular base (sechs Felder des Kreuzgewölbes). There was one more panel in the corners (in den Ecken) of the cloister. The arcades of the cloister were open toward the yard. There was a quadrangular masonry cistern (Zisterne) in the south-western corner of the yard (in the south-eastern corner in Somogyvár) of a capacity of more than 400 hi. This collected the rain water running down from the roofs of the monastery (Klosterdächern) since there was no well here (Brunnen). (There was no well at Somogyvár either.) Potable water was gained from a streamlet and a nearby spring (just like in So mogyvár). A water conduit (Nutzwasser) carried the water into the cistern (we have not found it but it was uncovered at Pilisszentkereszt). The surplus water was carried away in a stone channel (durch einen steingemauerten Kanal) in the southern wing of the monastery. (It was exactly the same in So mogyvár only the brick channel ran under the eastern wing: Figs. 939, 1275, 1276, 2349). In 1974, a water conduit made of 16th-17th century ceramic pipes (Wasserleitung aus Keramikro hren) was uncovered, which carried here water from a nearby spring. (Nothing similar was found in Somogyvár). The deceased monks were buried in the interior yard of the monastery (die Fläche des inneren Klosterhofes). Fifty-one graves were uncovered in 1972-75. Most of them were dis turbed by later burials. (In Somogyvár, there were no graves in the yard only in the cloister.)
A few bodies lay in expensive stone caskets (in aufwandrei chen Steinkisten), others in wooden coffins (in Holzsärgen), and yet others were wrapped in linen. Only a single grave con tained grave goods. There were burials not only in the yard but also under the pavement of the cloister (unter dem Fussboden des Klosterganges). According to Nándor Knauz’s investigations in the late 19th century, there also were burials in the sacristy and the church but they were too disturbed to be worth uncovering. The economic buildings of the monastery probably stood west of the investigated territory, perhaps on the territory of the yard filled in in the late renaissance period. The gothic gate (das gotische Tor) of the monastery proba bly stood at the north-western projection (Risalit) of the build ings. The segments of the arch of the gate (Segmente des Torbo gens) were walled in into a chamber on the ground floor (Kammer im Parterre), while a late gothic niche (Sedile) was built into the drive-way of the western wall (Unterfahrt). At the same time, a door was built into the room on its eastern side. The buildings east of the gate were two-storied (stocking). The walled up upstairs windows appeared in the stone wall (steinere Gewände) in the 16th century filling (im Interieur des Schütt bodens). Significant changes happened here in the renaissance pe riod, especially in the second half of the 16th century. A strong fortification was built against the Turkish threat (türkische Ge fahr). Soon afterwards, in 1565, the king (Ferdinand I) donated the abbey abandoned by the Benedictine monks in 1542 to the chapter of Esztergom. This reconstructed renaissance fortification has been pre served to our days (while Somogyvár was finally abandoned in 1555/56). The fortification had a trapezoid ground plan and it was three times larger than the territory of the original monastery (dreifache der Ausdehnung). From among the older buildings, the entire eastern facade was used and lengthened toward south, just like the church with the northern wing of the mon astery and, in the north, the old watchtower (der ältere Wehr turm) with the gate (Eingangstor). The southern and the west ern wings of the former monastery were pulled down. Strong, multi-storied, cylindrical bastions (Basteien) with loop-holes were raised on the south-western and south-eastern corners. The south-western bastion has been preserved in an intact shape. The church was also rebuilt. The original gothic windows (gotische Fenster) were bricked up, the exterior main walls (Umfassungsmauer) were raised and loop-holes were built over the vault (über dem Gewölbe) on the lower levels from where the defenders could look out in every direction. The central renaissance fortification was surrounded by an exte rior wall with two yet preserved gates: the so-called Black Gate was on the northern side and the so-called Abacialka on the southern side. The church of the Saint Giles monastery of Somogyvár was not completely rebuilt like the Garamszentbenedek one in the late 14th century (it was already finished in 1405), but the freshly built pillars of the church supported only a ribbed groin vault here as well. The monastery was not rebuilt at either set tlements in the Anjou period only repairs were made (claust rum reparavit), but both became richer and more complex (Fig. 1047). This was the time when the western wing was built on the northern side of the gate house at Somogyvár. Granaries and stalls occupied its ground floor and a conversus was fur



604 SOMOGYVÁR - Szent Egyed-monostor
nished upstairs. Its measurements (L: 18 m) afford this supposi tion (Fig. 1103). In the northeast, a larger infirmary could be established perhaps with a warming room (calefactorium), in the place of the former churchyard, where a few graves have been uncovered (Figs. 980, 1480). The monastery was probably two-storied except for the southern side. From a western approach, the cloister is the cen tre of a monastery, so a great attention was paid to it even though Benedictine abbeys were considerably independent and first of all the local conditions determined the style and the character of the buildings. The basic theories were, however, respected maybe not exactly according to the designs of the Sankt Gallen monastery (around 830) which was considered a model. A monastery built on the northern side of the church is not a common solution although it often occurred at the Benedic tine and other orders as well. The most important Hungarian examples are the Observant Franciscan monasteries of Vértesszentkereszt, Budaszentlőrinc and Szeged. In West Eu rope, the Cistercian monastery of Eberbach, the Maulbronn, the Senanque monasteries, the Cistercian monastery of Le Thoronet and the Hammersleben monastery of the Augustine order can be mentioned. The sacristy, the chapterhouse, the chapel can be found on the eastern side, the gatehouse, the converses are located on the western side independent of the fact if the block of the monas tery was in the south or the north. The dormitory and the locutory were either in the southern or the northern wing, farther from the church. The cloister was joined to the northern wall of the church most probably with a wooden half saddle roof. The door open ing into the church was generally very decorative. Its place was found between the third and the fourth pillars and pilas ter strips although barely any trace was left of it since the northern wall was blown up with gunpowder in the 19th cen tury.
