Some of the carvings of the gates must have come from the northern gate (Figs. 2353, 2354). On the other sides, the cloister was vaulted in the 13th-14th centuries when the columns, column heads and arches were prepared according to a profuse sculptural program. The sculp tural ornaments, especially the column heads were continu ously carved for decades. The column heads decorated with vine leaves and bunches of grapes probably belonged to the cloister. The arcaded cloister remained open toward the yard until the second half of the 15th century when it was pulled down to the parapet wall and the single, double and five-fold column foots, the sandstone and marble column shafts and the single, double and fivefold column heads, the archivolts and other arch fragments were built in elsewhere or discarded. Var ious fragments that had come from here were found on the en tire territory of Kupavár. The reconstruction of the 15th century cloister is uncertain since although the parapet wall was found (Fig. 597), the func tion of the prismatic brick columns (Figs. 595, 596, 598) could not be determined. The levels of the late medieval brick floors (Figs. 599, 601, 607-611) indicated the reduced corridor of the cloister but the role of the monastery wings has not been clari fied. Perhaps the new situation resembled Altenberg where the western wing of the romanesque Cistercian monastery fell rather far from the claustrum In Somogyvár, the southern and the eastern sides certainly remained unchanged, the northern and the western sides could be modified and perhaps a western yard was also established.
All the finds and features (ovens, hearths, burials) indicated that the inhabitants of the monastery continuously used the largest part of the original wings until the middle of the 16th century irrespective of their technical condition. The rooms on the ground floor of the northern wing were always covered with a flat ceiling of wooden beams (Figs. 806, 807, 812, 817, 820): the long oak beams were preserved in a burnt condition lying in a west-east direction in the upper most, 16th century layer. Based on the lead water conduit (Figs. 840, 856) found in the northern wall and according to the cellar and the kitchen supposed above it and the neigh bourhood of the bake house, this room is interpreted as the refectory of the monks. The doors of both the kitchen and the refectory could be identified but the place of the door frame with a ledger is not known (Fig. 2358). We also do not known to which room of the monastery the tracery windows (Figs. 1036, 2152, 2155) and the mullioned windows of pear-ele ments belonged, the jambs and components of which could be refitted. Probably the eastern wing, where the chapter house (capitulum) and the scriptorium were furnished with hot-air floor and wall heating, was more decorative. According to the pillar remains preserved in the centre, they were vaulted. The chapter house was generally close to the church and the sacristy in the most significant part of the cloister. In the Middle Ages, the cloister was originated from the hall of Solomon’s church where the apostles vowed to com munal life and the community of goods (vita communis). The first chapter house was built in the Heiligenberg monastery at Heidelberg around 1030 and from that time it was also the burial place of the abbots and sometimes of the founders as well. This could be one of the reasons why its back part was joined to the Mary chapel, which also served as a funeral chapel. We uncovered two graves (of abbots?) (graves nos. 133 and 470: Figs. 948, 949, 956, 967, 968) and the chapel (Figs. 884, 939). The dormitory could be on the first floor in the eastern wing (similarly to the Eberbach dormitories built in the 12th-14th centuries) and the room on the southern side of the small (Vir gin Mary?) chapel can perhaps be interpreted as a staircase (Figs. 912, 913). Naturally, the dormitory and the cells of the monks had many windows in Somogyvár. The functions of the rooms are difficult to tell from the foundation walls and we know even less about the upper floors. It will never be discovered where the locutory (parlatorium, au ditorium), the prayer room (oratorium), the school (schola), the refectory and the dormitory of the laymen, the guesthouse (hospicium) could be. There certainly were a library (biblio theca) and a scriptorium since the Saint Giles monastery was one of the loca credibilia where many documents, formularies and codices were edited. In this respect, the archaeological finds can help since relatively many metal and bone book cover mounts and a few early styluses (12th-13th centuries) (stylus: Figs. 1352, 1354) have been unearthed. Not only a formulary but also a 12th century papal bulla at tests to the existence of a document collection (Fig. 1369). The number of 13th-14th century book mount types is low (Figs. 415, 880, 1261, 1293, 1773), most of the book clasps, sliding buttons and corner-pieces (nearly 40 items) were made in the 15th century. Beside plain ones (Figs. 726, 762, 1291), there were mounts with letter ornaments (AVE MARIA: Fig. 66; AV MI: Figs. 985, 1259, 1283), vegetal patterns (Fig. 1158) and eagles (Fig. 1321). Round, square-shaped and open-work central mount (Figs. 842, 880, 1428, 1589), corner-pieces with



Historical recapitulation 605
open-work, schematic vegetal ornaments (Figs. 1070, 1248, 1259, 1282, 83, 1291, 1292, 1321, 1428, 1589) were the com mon types from the 1470/80’s. There were also bone cornerpieces (Fig. 878). The size of the book stock of the Somogy monastery is dif ficult to estimate since although we have not found traces of a pyre, both the church and the monastery suffered from a severe destruction. As para 53 of the Regula prescribes hand washing (aquam in manibus abbas hospitibus det), there had to be a place for the purpose of washing, bathing. The foundation (Figs. 553, 554, 558, 817) topped by a statue (Saint Giles?) uncovered in the north-western quarter of the yard is interpreted as an orna mental fountain. The traces of the lead water pipe were also found in the north (Fig. 840, 856) but we have not found a bath room (balnearium). We know next to nothing about the furniture (tables, chairs, benches, beds, shelves, cases, chests (toregma) of the monastic rooms. The remains of lighting were better preserved. Imported ol ive oil was used in the lamps (Figs. 1023, 1101, 1174), and wax candles were lit in the wrought iron armed wall candlesticks and the bronze table candlesticks (Figs. 444, 446, 853, 902, 1416, 1443, 1563, 1777). Most of the balustered cast and then polished candlestick shafts, holders prepared with winged feet and the foot-rings hammered from round copper plates came from the 15th century although there are earlier items as well among the iron specimens. The small construction jutting out at the eastern edge of the northern wing was perhaps the remains of a latrine (latrinae) similarly to the north-eastern “stone closets” of the eastern wing (see the complex ground plan at the end of volume I). The graves of the inhabitants of the Somogyvár monastery, the monks, the laymen who were not ordained, their families, the servants and armed knights could most probably be found on the territory of the monastery and in the basilica, while the population of the town of Somogyvár (urbs, oppidum) mostly but not exclusively, buried their dead in the cemetery around the chapel. Numerous bodies were buried under the pavement of the cloister inside the monastery (191 individuals) but only the graves of 77 individuals could be distinguished by grave num bers among them possibly Benedictine monks living here be tween 1091 and 1553/56. The distribution by gender was 87 males, 48 females and 38 infants. The expensive stone casket graves (Figs. 727, 731-733 , 734) most probably contained the bodies of nobles who may have arrived from the south, the Dalmatian coast, where stone casket graves had been in fash ion for centuries. Brick graves were also frequently made (Fig. 948). They lay under the brick pavement and the parapet wall of the late medieval cloister often intersected these graves (Figs. 601, 607, 609, 611, 692), so most of these burials are dated from the 12th-14th century, although certain graves could come from the 15th-16th centuries since the brick pave ment could be taken up. The average age of the adults buried in the quadrum barely surpassed 32 years. The anthropological types are varied: they must have come from different places. The teeth show an aver age wear, the number of anomalies is not extreme but only a few examples can be mentioned in lack of a detailed analysis. For example, in vivo broken ribs, vertebral wounds (grave no. 54), the ossification of finger bones (grave no. 70), an in vivo broken tibia (grave no. 71) could be observed.
From among the economic buildings of the Saint Giles monastery, only the kitchen (coquina: Figs. 770,1509), the bake house (Fig. 1119), the cellar (cellarium: Figs. 770, 771, 779-787, 1501, 1504), and the ice-pit (Figs. 1044, 1419-1421, 1423,1432, 1455) could more or less certainly be identified. We could only suppose the existence of casting workshops (Figs. 283, 1122, 1123), pottery kilns (Figs 307, 308), a corn-mill (mola: Figs. 1107-1109, 1113) and a butchery or slaughter house (Figs. 1364, 1370, 1374). Most certainly baking ovens stood along the interior of the castle wall and at the edge of the ditch (Figs. 2025, 2031, 2032, 2070-2081, 2211, 2224), which the pottery finds and the coins certainly date from the llth -13th centuries. The Benedictine order played an important role in the eco nomic life of Hungary as well, so the preserved implements, tools, vessels, accessories are important indicators. They are, however, difficult to ascribe to chronological groups and even more difficult to date. The preserved and uncovered tools do not reveal the quality and extent of the contemporary economic activity since iron and other metal objects were too expensive to be readily discarded. It is conspicuous that only two cleaving chisels (Figs. 329, 814), two indented chisels (Fig. 1067) and an iron pick (Fig. 564) have been preserved from the tool kits of stone carvers working on the huge constructions. There are smaller chisels (Figs. 592, 870, 2186), which were probably used by locksmiths. A hewing axe (Fig. 1550), an asymmetrical axe (Fig. 1015), socketed hatchets (Fig. 1192), a broad axe without a peen (Fig. 802), a turning tool (Fig. 1295) and a plane-iron (Fig. 2194) belonged to carpenters and joiners. The number of drills is significant (Fig. 5 2 6 ,7 6 8 ,8 1 9 ,1 3 9 1 ,1 7 5 1 , 2021, 2095). A few winged drills were also uncovered (Figs. 821, 1025). At the same time, there is not a single ploughshare or coul ter in the find material counting 149 thousand items. There are also few goads (Fig. 1440) used for the cleaning of the spades and the ploughshares (perhaps the socket of a spade can also be grouped here: Figs. 1080 and 552). There are two hoes (Fig. 1285), a hay/straw prong (Fig. 2188), a pruning knife (Fig. 2088) and a crescent-shaped hand knife (Fig. 2104). In contrast, there were many sickles and whetstones, while only a single fragment of a scythe blade was found. Most of the iron sickles were broken: blade fragments with the neck and the tang were generally preserved (Fig. 603, 614, 1217, 1403, 2033, 2069). The bolster ring of the handle was also preserved on a 125 mm long tang (Fig. 1386). Two of the blades (Figs. 5 5 5,1149,1358, 1473) bear a stamp of an eight-branched star within a circle (Figs. 859,1306). A long-necked sickle of an indented edge was also found (Fig. 1491, 1503). Sickles cannot practically be dated: they were used in the 12th-14th centuries just as well as in the 15th-16th centuries. The worn whetstones were simply discarded. There were items kept in sheaths and ones hanging from a string (Figs. 270, 1029, 1405, 2023, 1348, 1373). From among the tools of animal keeping, horseshoes and curb bits help dating the most, all the other implements are timeless. The curb bits with long cheek-pieces and spherical mouth pieces, sometimes with curb chains (Figs. 838, 854, 1095, 1152, 1596) are 15th-16th century types, the snaffle bits, among them the ones with conical axes (Figs. 587,1096,1433), and one with a ring in the middle of the mouthpiece (Figs. 546, 1159, 1167, 1303,1522,1759, 2192) can be dated from the 13th-14th centu ries. The strap buckles (Fig. 826, 924, 969, 984, 1028, 1064,



606 SOMOGYVÁR - Szent Egyed-monostor
1572), the chains, the chain terminals and chain terminals with pivoting rings are just as unsuitable for exact dating as the tools of grooming. Farrier’s tongs (Fig. 818), hoof knives (Fig. 2067), curry combs (Figs. 767,1 1 6 9 ,1 3 3 2 ,1 7 5 6 ) were tried and tested tools used for centuries similarly to hammers (Figs. 392, 852). The relatively high number of cart mountings, which were found on the territories of the monastery and the castle, offers a better insight in the economic life of the abbey. From among the iron fittings of wheels, the ones with two nail holes dominate (Figs. 545, 588, 612, 1093, 1469, 1601, 1749, 2049, 2099), while fragments with a single nail hole are less numerous (Figs. 588 and 1997). A few pole mountings (Figs. 1077), wheel mountings (Fig. 1091), wheel nails (Figs. 1087, 1513), stake mountings from the rack of the cart (cart-ladder) (Figs. 267, 963), forage ladder pegs (Fig. 1782), perhaps a gag ring (Fig. 778), and the Anstock-rings (Figs. 777, 1334, 2048) can uniformly be dated from the 16th century although these types certainly exited ear lier and later as well. Somogyvár was finally abandoned around 1556 and so no items younger than the middle of the 16th cen tury occur apart from a few modern period pipe fragments (Figs. 815, 1191, 1241,2172). Scissors, thimbles and needles can be mentioned from the various household tools. Beside scissors with short blades and returned, open rings (Figs. 527, 851, 1323, 1342, 1594, 1758, 2056), and similar, large tailoring scissors (Figs. 1068, 1476), scissors with closed rings (Figs. 869, 1065, 1215, 1393, 1395, 1476,1758) were also used in the 14th-16th centuries, they are not exclusively characteristic of the 16th-17th centuries. There is a scissor stamp at the end of one of the pointed arms of a sheep-shears (Fig. 2072). Copper thimbles (Figs. 839, 962, 977, 1343) were mass pro duced from the 15th century. Only a single needle was found from bone (Fig. 529), there were each a bronze and an iron net needle (Figs. 590, 1367) and also an iron basket weaving needle (Fig. 2173). There were also a few simple spindle-whorls made from the bottoms of vessels (Figs. 1022/7, 1037, 1764, 2100) among the tools of women but there was not a single comb. From the building accessories, nails, door mountings, door handles (Fig. 1006), bolts, iron bolt tops, hinges, flap hinges, knockers (Fig. 1196) and locks (Fig. 1299, 1762) were uncovered in large numbers. The number of keyhole shields (Figs. 464, 816, 970, 2185), bolts (Figs. 882, 888, 965, 1353), lock tongues (Fig. 457, 827, 1041) and traditional door and padlock keys (Figs. 703, 1269,1486, 2020) is relatively signifi cant. Most of the hidden iron tool finds (hoards) came from the 16th-17th centuries (Decs-Ete, Cegléd-Gubodi út, Rákoscsaba, Csongrád-Bokros, etc.). In Somogyvár, however, the finds are not younger than the middle of the 16th century. Most of the iron tools came from the 15th-16th centuries. They also include padlocks and hobble padlocks, among which there are 14th century types as well (Figs. 471, 1183, 2041), most of them, however, are 15th century quadrangular items with semicircu lar bows and cylindrical keyholes (Figs. 524, 761, 857, 1004, 1307, 1327, 1330, 1331, 1494, 2005, 2108, 2110). Cylindrical padlocks with arched bows were also in fashion for centuries (between the 13th and the 16th centuries) (Figs. 763, 1328, 1435,1494,1573), and they were often used for locking hobbles (Fig. 561). We cannot or do not dare to distinguish the archaeological evidences of the economic boom of the Hungarian Kingdom in the Anjou period although numerous tool types certainly ex
isted already in the 13th-14th centuries, which is evidently proved by the ceramic material. Among the weapons, a group of arrowheads (Figs. 887, 997, 1452,1492,1608,1774), the pommel of a two-edged sword (Fig. 1030), the blade fragment of another sword (Fig. 1072), a frag ment of a chain armour (Fig. 926), a socketed iron spearhead (Fig. 1355), the socket of another spearhead (Fig. 274), the orna mental bronze chape of a sword (Fig. 1278), copper mounts from the mouth and the terminal of the sheath of a dagger (Figs. 1050, 2086), a large fragment of a plate helmet with a neck piece (Fig. 1072), and iron daggers (Figs. 2089, 2093) came from the Árpádian and the Anjou periods (12th-14th centuries). There are 13th century items among the socketed and tanged arrow heads for arbalests although the majority came from the 15th16th centuries (Figs. 525, 563, 996, 1308, 1310, 1556, 2038, 2158, 2189). The largest group of the 16th century weapons is composed of axe-adzes (battle axes) (Fig. 273), although carefully finished battle axe-adzes were also found (Fig. 534) and even a small, cast bronze axe-adze (Fig. 797) was uncovered. Beside a slightly arched sabre blade and a short blade fragment of a two-edged sword (Figs. 276, 1347), a simple cross-bar of a sword turned back in an S shape (Fig. 1225) and two iron maces of four and six flanges (Figs. 384,1499) were also uncovered. The fact that a dagger was placed into a coffin beside the body even in the sec ond half of the 15th century shows the popularity of iron dag gers (Figs. 1819,1820). The number of fire-arms is insignificant. Apart from the fragment of the barrel fragment of a harquebus (Fig. 299) and another strange iron tube fragment (Fig. 1593), practically only two bullet casting pliers (Figs. 849, 2190) and a dozen of lead bullets represent the fire-arms of the 16th century. From among the blazing arms of the period, an iron plate and a cast shrapnel have been preserved (Figs. 1309,1437). The rooms of the monastery had to be heated with stoves, ovens (Fig. 1771), and sometimes floor heating. The cooks had to fry and cook in the kitchens and besides bread and cakes had to be baked in the ovens. Naturally, pottery and wooden vessels dominated among the kitchen utensils, al though iron pots (Figs. 960, 1500), copper bowls or cauldrons (Figs. 1177, 1357), pans (Figs. 918, 1121) and iron ladles (Fig. 1002) were also used. Numerous copper plates were uncovered (Fig. 272), their function, however, cannot be determined. The preserved items can most probably be dated from the 14th-16th centuries. There are unique items as well like a fragment of an aquamanile decorated with an animal head (Fig. 2163) from the Árpádian period. It is interesting that only two iron strike-a-lights have been found (Figs. 825, 891). The remains of the hearths do not afford a reconstruction although many scattered cup-shaped stove and oven tiles were uncovered in a fragmentary condition (Figs. 1063, 1588, 1763). At the same time, the number of decorated and figurái stove tiles is unexpectedly low. Beside green glazed fragments with floral motives (Figs. 538, 2007, 2022), small fragments of also green-glazed tiles with lion (Figs. 828, 855), dragon (Fig. 1290) and bird figures (Figs. 1454,1564,1657,1765) have been identi fied. On a small fragment, a yellowish brown glaze can be ob served (Fig. 1454). Among the unglazed tiles, there is a plate shaped item with a six-branched star (Fig. 1381), ones with geometric patterns (Figs. 831, 832), floral motives (Figs. 517, 1063), and small fragments of tracery top and corner tiles (Figs. 1434, 1561, 1780, 2012, 2087). They can be dated from the 15th



Historical recapitulation 607
century, although stoves had a long life-span. There are no ren aissance items in the find material. Instead, the traces of 15th century tracery and blind tracery tiles can be demonstrated (Figs. 998, 2166). The huge number of shards evidently attests to continuous life on the territory of Kupavár of Somogyvár from the 11th century to the middle of the 16th century. The majority of the early potteries came from the interior of the castle north of the monastery: this area was probably barely used after the 14th century. The 11th-12th century, poorly fired vessels were generally made on a slow wheel. They are decorated with wavy lines in cised by a dense comb (Figs. 1016/15, 2000), broad wavy lines impressed with a stick (Figs. 493, 864, 1016/17, 1361, 1592, 1779), rows of wavy lines (Figs. 537, 796, 1016/16, 1151, 2034, 2036/3) or spiral motives running around the vessel (Figs. 616, 1016/20, 2086/3). Yellowish white, brownish grey flasks (Figs. 497, 800, 805, 957, 969, 990, 1022/5) and handled jugs (Figs. 834, 1016/5,8,9, 1084,1251) were new vessel types in the 12th century. The han dles were often decorated with oblique grooves and impressed dot rows, crosses (Figs. 496,628) or a herringbone pattern (Figs. 1016/9, 1178). These vessels often bear a stamp on the bottom probably because they were placed with the mouth downwards on the shelves or the bottle-drainer. Several groups can be dis tinguished: a/ simple, even-armed cross (Figs. 304, 383, 453, 830, 905, 955, 1011, 1129, 1179, 2036/5,7); b/ even-armed cross in a circle (Figs. 498,858,955,1022/1,4, 1023, 1101, 1151/2, 1174/1,2,4 1390, 2036/6, 2101, 2133); cl swastika in itself or in a square (Figs. 540, 1166, 1420, 2165); d/ grid pattern, which can be interpreted as a double or a triple, i.e. papal cross (Figs. 498, 874,1390); e/ diagonal cross (St. Andrew’s cross) in a square (Fig. 1174/5); f/ Latin cross in a circle (Fig. 2165); g/ sphere-terminal cross (Fig. 2036/4); h/ forking cross in itself or in an oval frame (Figs. 905,1246); h/ three-step ladder (Fig. 540); i/ crosses with three-branched forking (Fig. 1022/3); j/ divers (Fig. 992). Clay cauldrons (Figs. 461, 521, 966, 971, 1496, 1999, 2111) can also be grouped among the 11th-12th century potteries. The number and diversity of vessels suddenly increased in the 12th-13th centuries. Flasks of red and brown painting (Figs. 200, 455, 915, 2061), mugs (Figs. 199, 1022/9-11), spouted jugs (Fig. 999), small white cups (Fig. 1085), roulette-ornamented pots (Figs. 798, 1184, 2036/1), pots with wavy and spiral line decorations (Figs. 790, 1016/19, 2036/2), kitchen wares with oblique notches (Figs. 1016/12,13,14,18, 1752, 2036/8) ap peared. Wavy lines, rows of crosses and roulette patterns often ran along the interior rims of bowls (Figs. 858/1,2, 1088, 1242, 1388). Many vessels were intact or could be refit (Figs. 204, 304, 383, 398, 447, 448, 453, 455, 470, 544, 874, 1011-14, 1018-20, 1102, 1127-1134, 1817, 2061, 2080, 2132-2134) among them early types of lamps or cups (Figs. 1022/1,2,4, 1023, 1101, 1174/1,2) including ones with bottom stamps. The ceramic finds are the indicators and evidences of the bus tling life of the Saint Giles monastery in the 13th-15th centuries. Most of them were made on fast wheels turned by the feet, and the proportion of goods imported from abroad also increased.
The import of graphitic storage vessels fired in a reducing atmos phere started in the 13th century and increased in the 15th-16th centuries since graphite cannot be found in the Carpathian Ba sin. Stamps can be observed on the rims or the handles of most of the graphitic kitchen wares (pots, jugs) and storage vessels (Fig. 795). On the items from Somogyvár, crosses with four dots, coats-of-arms with seven bands (Figs. 518/1,2, 794, 795, 877), footed crosses in coats-of-arms (Figs. 518/3-7, 898, 989, 1001, 1075, 1163, 1185, 1384), and less frequently a letter T occurred (Fig. 799). These are vessels used for storing oil, lard and wine, and, as far as we can tell, they were prepared in Tullin (letter T), Vienna (vertical cross with a beam on top), Passau-Hafnerzell (cross stamp), Ried and Salzburg (double stamps) in the 14th16th centuries. They are generally decorated with tendril motives or patterns impressed with a stick (Figs. 988,1185), and they are large, sometimes even huge. The simpler local types survived beside the imported wares (Figs. 1016/1,2,11, 1022/6) especially in the groups of bowls (Figs. 900, 1016/4), strainers (Figs. 619, 957, 2024) and smooth ers cut from pottery vessels (Figs. 1554). The ornamental vessels, first of all tumblers and goblets of stamped ornaments (Figs. 326, 406, 493, 520, 557, 1016/3, 1300, 1560), are mostly finds from the 15th century, and most of the utensils imported from abroad also belong here. The Lostice tumblers (Figs. 602, 829, 895,916) and the fragments of a stoneware with a bean pattern (Fig. 286), and a painted stoneware (Fig. 1320) attest to the flourishing life of the 14th15th centuries. The fragments of thin-walled, finely tempered yellow mugs and three-lobed cups (Figs. 494, 1012, 1387, 1559) form a spe cial group, which is completed with a series of yellow, footed goblets and beakers (Figs. 515, 556, 804, 889, 974, 1098, 1250, 1287, 1562, 1779). Naturally, most of the intact or nearly intact vessels were preserved from the 15th-16th centuries (Figs. 201, 203, 448, 458, 860, 956, 974, 1011, 1182, 1817). The vessels that could be refitted to a significant degree are also the relics of the final pe riod (Figs. 470, 788, 833, 973, 975). Beside the finger impressed and foveolate ornaments (Figs. 789, 1057) of the youngest 16th century vessels, brown and green glazed pots and pans (Figs. 995, 1392) are also represented in the find material.
Despite its richness, the find material uncovered during the ar chaeological investigation of the Saint Benedict royal abbey of Somogyvár and its defence works between 1972 and 2009 il lustrates only a morsel of the contemporary life. According to our estimations, only 6-7% of the carved stone material has been uncovered and the whole of the finds make no more than 10% of the material remains of the half a thousand years of the functioning of the monastery. The number of the individuals buried here does not even reach half of the persons that once lived and died here.
***
The dream of the archaeologist concerning the complete exca vation has not become true. Similarly to the very first archeoló gián explorer Péter Gerecze at the end of the 19th century. However, the hope must be there that some day a successor will be able to accomplish this great but yet unfinished work.
